para.paratext: Georgia has adopted the more liberal federal rule on agency admissions in O.C.G.A. § 24-8-801(d)(2)(D), which excludes from hearsay any statements by a “party's agent or employee … concerning a matter within the scope of the agency or employment, made during the existence of the relationship.” The rule further provides that “the contents of the statement shall be considered but shall not alone be sufficient to establish the … agency or employment relationship and scope thereof.”

Under this rule, an agency admission is allowed even where agents and employees have no actual authority to speak for the principal. Fed. R. Evid. 801(d)(2)(D) does not require that the statement be made by the employee at the instance of her employer but only that the declarant's statement “concern matters within the scope of her agency or employment.”[1] The court rather than the jury decides whether the foundation for an admission is sufficient.[2]

Admissions by other agents or representatives may be admissible against the party-opponent, including those made by attorneys at law,[3] partners,[4] coconspirators,[5] administrators or executors,[6] a principal as binding his surety,[7] and admissions made in appellate briefs.[8] Also, a lawyer's failure to respond during trial to something an opposing lawyer said is an admission by silence.[9]

Citing applicable federal case law in interpreting this exception, the Georgia Court of Appeals noted in State v. Wood[10] that an attorney's statements are admissible against a defendant in criminal cases.

The primary evidence question that arises regarding admissions by agents involves statements by nonmanagement employees. The binding effect of statements by individuals with apparent authority to represent a principal is a question of substantive agency law.[11]

Statements by members of an organization's management group, including its board of directors, are generally considered admissions by alter egos of the organization[12] unless the facts show that the statements were outside the scope of the individual's authority or the party claiming to have relied on the statements was on actual notice of restrictions to the individual's authority.[13]

The determination of whether an employee's statement was made in the scope and course of employment involves a common sense analysis of the specific facts.[14] Under the above guidelines, statements by a store employee immediately after the plaintiff fell on slippery ice in the store's parking lot, that several other people had complained about slipping on ice, but store employees were too busy to take care of the problem, were held admissible.[15]

Historically in Georgia, admissions by an agent or employee have been received in evidence if that person was authorized to speak on behalf of the principal.[16] Georgia case law in this area is muddled because two statutes, former O.C.G.A. § 24-3-33[17] from the Evidence Code and former O.C.G.A. § 10-6-64[18] from the Commerce and Trade Code, addressed agent admissions in different language. In 1991, the Georgia Court of Appeals case Uniflex Corp. v. Saxon[19] held that O.C.G.A. § 24-3-33 must be construed together with O.C.G.A. § 10-6-64 so that an agent's statements are admissible against his principal if they were part of the res gestae of the transaction at issue in the case. Several subsequent cases used this approach, but the res gestae limitation was not applied in all cases in which agency admissions were offered into evidence.

In Rowell v. Bellsouth Corp.,[20] the Eleventh Circuit held that a supervisor's admission that an employee was fired because of his age was inadmissible opinion because he was not involved in the decision to terminate the employee.

In other cases, such statements have been admitted to prove that the principal had notice or knowledge of certain facts acknowledged by the agent. In Taylor v. Golden Corral Corp.,[21] the restaurant manager's statement that an employee had mopped up a spaghetti spill from the area in which the plaintiff had slipped and fallen was an admission against the restaurant's interest within the scope of the manager's employment and admissible because it related to the restaurant's knowledge of the hazardous condition.
All statements made by lawyers, regarding matters they are handling for clients are admissions of their clients if the statements are made during the period of employment.[22] This includes:
statements in conversations with opposing attorneys during the course of litigation;[23]
statements made in letters to opposing attorneys during the court of litigation;[24]
statements made in pleadings;[25]
statements in summary judgment briefs;[26]
statements made to the jury during trial;[27]
statements made in appellate briefs.[28]
It has also been held that an attorney's failure to respond during trial to something an opposing attorney said is an admission by silence.[29]

However, admissions by agents or attorneys are not admissible in criminal cases in the sense in which they are admissible in civil cases. They should not be treated as evidence against the accused unless shown to have been authorized by him.[30]

“The relation of principal and agent arises wherever one person, expressly or by implication, authorizes another to act for him or subsequently ratifies the acts of another in his behalf.” O.C.G.A. § 10-6-1.

The distinguishing characteristic of an “agent” is that he is vested with authority, real or ostensible, to create obligations on behalf of his principal, bringing third parties into contractual relations with him. Physician Specialists in Anesthesia, P.C. v. Wildmon, 238 Ga. App. 730, 732 (1), 521 S.E.2d 358 (1999).

Where the agent can be considered the alter ego of the principal (such as a corporation's president) and the agent speaks while in the due performance of his official duties relating to the transaction involved, such admissions “will be taken as being made by the corporation itself,” Williams v. City of Social Circle, 225 Ga. App. 746, 748, 484 S.E.2d 687 (1997), but not otherwise. City of Atlanta v. Broadnax, 285 Ga. App. 430, 436, 646 S.E.2d 279 (2007) (disapproved of on other grounds by, Royal Capital Development LLC v. Maryland Cas. Co., 291 Ga. 262, 728 S.E.2d 234 (2012)).

See Black v. New Holland Baptist Church, 122 Ga. App. 606, 609, 178 S.E.2d 571 (1970), which held that “[a] corporation is not bound by a declaration of an agent made outside the scope of his agency.” Statements by the church's treasurer to a church tenant about the church's legal responsibility regarding injuries at a house leased by the church were therefore held inadmissible against the church because the statements were outside the scope of the treasurer's scope of employment—he had no dealings with the church's rental property. Ga. Jur., Corporations § 5:2.

Khawaja v. Lane Co., Inc., 239 Ga. App. 93, 96, 520 S.E.2d 1 (1999) (corporate receptionist's statement to a process server that she was authorized to accept service of a lawsuit on behalf of corporation was held outside the scope of her employment and therefore not an admission by an agent).
Quiktrip Corp. v. Childs, 220 Ga. App. 463, 466, 469 S.E.2d 763 (1996).

O.C.G.A. § 24-8-821: “Without offering the same in evidence, either party may avail himself of allegations or admissions made in the pleadings of the other.”

Carver v. Saye, 198 Ga. App. 146, 147, 400 S.E.2d 683 (1990), held that former O.C.G.A. § 24-3-30 [§ 24-8-821 eff. Jan. 1, 2013] applied to answers as well as complaints and also held it proper to allow one party to cross-examine the opposing party regarding admissions and allegations in the opposing party's pleadings, without first introducing the pleadings. Carver also held it proper to cross-examine opposing parties regarding their pleadings after pre-trial order had been entered, even though these orders specify they “supersede the pleadings.” This is because the pleadings are not eliminated from cases in the evidentiary sense by pretrial orders; rather, pretrial orders supersede the pleadings as to the issues the issues to be tried.

The statute applies to allegations and admissions in pleadings even after a party withdraws them. Murphy v. Milo, 272 Ga. App. 200, 612 S.E.2d 56 (2005), in which the defendant's lawyer in a personal injury case stated during opening the defendant admitted liability. The plaintiff was nevertheless allowed to cross-examine the defendant regarding an answer filed on his behalf by a previous lawyer, which answer denied, among other things, the collision occurred where it did, he had been driving negligently, and the plaintiff was injured. The cross-examination questions were allowed over defendant's objection. The answer had been superseded by the pretrial order and was irrelevant because liability was admitted during the opening statement. The defendant was allowed to explain the denials in his answer after the cross-examination.
